sentences.sentence: With the passing on Easter Sunday of Robert Alexander Mundell (Oct. 24, 1932 - April 4, 2021), the world lost a great economist, Canada lost one of our greatest public intellectuals, and I lost a mentor and friend.
Awarded the Nobel Prize in Economics in 1999 (solo, not shared) and created a Companion of the Order of Canada in 2002, Bob, as we all called him, received every possible accolade.

Indeed, along with his sometime colleague at the University of Chicago, the late Milton Friedman, Mundell is widely acknowledged as the greatest macroeconomist of the second half of the last century, in the generation that followed John Maynard Keynes.While Friedman repudiated the Keynesian legacy, Bob built upon it.

The "Mundell-Fleming model," which remains to this day a workhorse for macroeconomic analysis in an open economy, is, at its core, an extension of Keynes' theories, as crystallized in the closed-economy "IS-LM" model of Sir John Hicks, who won the Nobel in 1972.

It's worth recalling that Mundell became intimately acquainted with Keynes' ideas during a stint at the London School of Economics in the late 1950s, studying with James Meade, an acolyte of the great Cambridge master.
Later, after completing a doctorate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he imbibed the ideas of the "other Cambridge" (i.e., Cambridge, Mass.

), Bob became a professor at Chicago in the late 1960s, where, with Friedman, he was primus inter pares amongst a bevy of great economists and future Nobel laureates, including George Stigler and many others.After a return to Canada in the early 1970s to head the Economics Department at the University of Waterloo, in 1974 Mundell joined the faculty of Columbia University in New York, where he remained for the rest of his career.

I got to know him there as a graduate student in economics in the early 1990s, when, as one of the few Canadians in the Ph.D. program, I was drawn into Bob's orbit almost as if by gravitational force.
Bob, in turn, became a mentor, then an advisor on my dissertation, and, finally, a lifelong friend.

Our paths crossed many times over the years, including two visits to speak at Carleton University at my invitation, and, more recently, as a member of the Santa Colomba Conference, which Bob convened and chaired just about every year at his Renaissance palazzo near Monteriggioni in the rolling hills of Tuscany.

The conference first convened on September 6, 1971, just weeks after U.S. treasury secretary, John Connally, at the behest of President Richard Nixon, closed the "gold window," effectively killing the postwar Bretton Woods system at one fell swoop and ushering us into the brave new world of flexible exchange rates.Robert Mundell, Canadian-born Nobel laureate who inspired the euro, dies at 88(https://financialpost.com/news/economy/robert-mundell-nobel-laureate-who-inspired-the-euro-dies-at-88)Terence Corcoran: Twenty years on, it's looking like Milton Friedman may have been right about the euro(https://financialpost.com/opinion/terence-corcoran-twenty-years-on-looks-like-milton-friedman-was-right-about-the-euro)The last meeting took place in 2019, and, as ever, involved a free flow of idea, argument, and debate about global economic issues.

Conversations at Santa Colomba, whether in the conference room or over the sumptuous lunches and dinners, with fine Tuscan wine always flowing, and with interlocutors both from within and outside the academy, taught me more about economics as a policy-relevant discipline than most of the rather sterile university seminars I was used to attending.Bob's being Canadian was not incidental to his achievements.

He was living in Canada in the 1950s when the country embarked on its experiment with flexible exchange rates, making us almost unique amongst major economies, and this shaped the path of Mundell's academic career and his single-minded focus on studying issues in the open economy, rather than the closed-economy analysis then the norm in the U.S. Ironically, while many, including the Bank of Canada, saw this early experience as vindicating flexible exchange rates, Bob saw in it a cautionary tale on the potentially destabilizing effects of what he always considered a non-system - in other words, the absence of a fixed exchange rate system - which, he came to believe, exacerbated volatility in exchange rates and capital flows, rather than doing the opposite, as its defenders, Friedman foremost amongst them, claimed.

Readers of this page will recall an almost legendary debate between Mundell and Friedman on the pros and cons of different exchange rate regimes back in 2000, perhaps the highest quality such public debate in recent years on an apparently arcane issue such as exchange rates.
(See elsewhere on this page.
)Looking back on a rich career that, remarkably, spanned more than six decades, it is impossible not to be struck by Bob's preternatural, and precocious, brilliance.

The Nobel citation, for example, rests on a half-dozen key papers - each one different from the others, each one pathbreaking - published from 1957 to 1963; that is, from the ages of 25 to 31, not forgetting that some of the underlying research dates back to his days as a graduate student, when he was even younger.

What is more, each carved out a terrain of economic theory rich with policy implications - whether on the choice of exchange rate regimes, the just balance between fiscal and monetary policy to stabilize the economy, or on how to manage economic fluctuations in a world of open capital markets.
In this sense, Mundell was, truly, both a Wunderkind and a prophet of our globalized world.Vivek Dehejia is associate professor of economics and philosophy at Carleton University.
